Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Undergraduate Research in Modeling and Computation for Discovery of Molecular Probes for SARS-CoV-2 Proteins
Award.AbstractNarration: This REU Site award to Northeastern University, located in Boston, MA, will support the training of six students for 10 weeks during the summer of 2020. Because of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the recommendation to maintain social distancing, students will virtually contribute to computational research projects focused on COVID-19. The Northeastern University REU Site will recruit a total of six students, primarily from colleges with limited research opportunities or who are from an under-represented group, to be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted and many will present the results of their work at future scientific conferences. Assessment of the program will be done through the online SALG URSSA tool. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. <br/><br/>The primary focus of this undergraduate research program will be for the students to learn about and use computational techniques that will be applied to urgent research questions surrounding the functions and control mechanisms of the SARS-CoV-2 proteins. Each student will be trained in some of the following skills: molecular modeling, ligand docking, molecular dynamics simulations, biomolecular electrostatics, and quantum mechanical electronic structure calculations. Students will analyze SARS-CoV-2 proteins and screen libraries of small molecules that can bind to and control these proteins. They will be mentored by three faculty members and six graduate students from the departments of Chemistry and Chemical Biology and Bioengineering at Northeastern University. They will contribute critical new knowledge about how the viral proteins function and how their function may be modulated. The students will also receive professional development training in areas such as research ethics, scientific writing, the graduate school application process, and resume writing. Participants will be selected by the PIs, based on applications consisting of college transcripts, personal statements, and letters of reference. Preference will be given to students who were accepted by another REU program that was subsequently cancelled because of the pandemic. More information about the program is available by contacting PI Dr. Mary Jo Ondrechen (mjo@neu.edu) or co-PIs Dr. Steven Lopez (s.lopez@northeastern.edu) and Dr. Mona Minkara (m.minkara@northeastern.edu).<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview and Background: This project originated in the 2020 pandemic when, because of widespread cancellations, most science majors across the country lost opportunities to gain research experience, earn a stipend, and build their careers in science through summer research programs in 2020. To respond to this educational crisis, three faculty members who specialize in theoretical and computational biology / chemistry at Northeastern University organized a virtual research experience for undergraduate students. Eight students participated in a 10-week summer program of research and career-building activities. After that first summer, noting the extent of lost opportunities for students because of the pandemic, the faculty provided part-time academic year research experiences for students to learn and perform research. A total of 14 undergraduate students were trained in computational chemistry / biology techniques and contributed to research projects using these techniques.

Intellectual Merit: Fourteen undergraduate students were trained in a variety of computational techniques, including molecular modeling, molecular dynamics, quantum chemistry techniques, protein electrostatics, and QM/MM methods. They participated in research projects and made discoveries pertaining to modeling of the lung surface - air interface, provided insights into the mechanism of photoswitching molecules in chemical biology, characterized the non-structural proteins of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, and analyzed the interactions between amino acids in enzymes to understand how they serve as catalysts. Students participated in career-building activities such as oral presentation practice, bioethics seminars, discussion of graduate school and fellowship opportunities, and conversation with a panel of recent PhDs about careers in industry. A faculty member from the University of Georgia surveyed the first set of participants before and after the summer of 2020 and showed that they gained self-efficacy and enhanced science identity upon completion of their summer research.

Broader Impacts: This project showed that it is possible to give undergraduate students a rigorous and meaningful research experience in a virtual environment when circumstances prohibit in-person research. Fourteen students expanded their knowledge and skills in computational biology / chemistry and gained research experience. Highly trained individuals in the field of computational chemistry / biology are in demand in the local high tech industries. These skills are vital to the regional high-tech economy of New England and to U.S. competitiveness in the global economy. Some of our participants have now graduated with their Bachelors degree; four are now in Ph.D. programs and one is in a Pharm.D. program.
